w:r.w:t: Ontos is a Databricks App extending Unity Catalog with important business functionality, including

& contracts, business glossaries, compliance checks, and more. While we are adding some rudimentary features to our platform now (that is, Databricks One, Discover Page, Governance Hub, Certification, Domains, Metrics), they are not sufficient for enterprise users to model their business efficiently. Ontos adds an
(where “ontos” is the root of word “ontology”) based approach that connects domains, products, glossaries in a hierarchical, semantic way. It also adds functionality for
, such as asset management for data stewards, or persona management for data security officers.
Stakeholders include someone that represents the customer(s) of this project and SMEs of any top-level architecture or processes that this project proposes changing.
Note: App not advertised yet, only word-of-mouth distribution.
Note: Also tracks customers who expressed interest but have yet to engage
targets nearly all of our enterprise customers
due to its range of features and its ability to improve the
governance stance holistically. Since it implements Data
Mesh concepts, namely Data Products, Data Contracts, and related reference metadata, it fits into common data governance practices.
Additionally, the following customers want to be able to link their data to industry standard ontologies (and/or build their own) and use that for discovery and validation of semantic consistency:
Once the app is ready, we are planning to follow through with these activities:
Note: Limited demos have already been given to selected customers and Partner UC SMEs and the feedback has always been positive.
Ontos builds natively on the Databricks platform, making use of all available features suitable for its purpose. For example, it uses the following:
Lakebase to store all the metadata it maintains, making the same available to the rest of the platform via our UC catalog support for Lakebase tables.
Lakeflow Jobs to run all heavy lifting jobs, like table copying or compliance checking.

Unity Catalog itself with Tag Policies to maintain tags and their assignment to data assets. This applies bidirectionally, as in either Ontos tags assets, or it scans the catalog for tagged assets and imports them into the app.
Genie spaces build directly from Data Products, grouping assets together based on their status and version.
across the entire platform as it improves discovery via its Data Product-based marketplace and, therefore, increases data processing via many channels, and appropriate for all business users.

While Ontos is covering more aspects of Data Governance, it is foremost aiming at better cataloging, discovery, and consumption. If you think about purchasing certain necessary items, you usually think about final products, not raw steel or even iron and carbon to make your own steel, but about a set of screws you need to build a cabinet, or an entire, already built cabinet. Products are aligned to where they are needed in the value chain, and have their own lineage connecting the screw to the hinge to the cabinet. Data-driven companies adopt this value chain thinking, defining products along the way. These products need lifecycle management and strict contracts between producers and consumers. On top they need to reflect the realm they implement. This means we have to overlay the product-thinking with business semantics, attaching meaning to each part of the value chain.

Ontos this by supporting the use of external taxonomies (maintained outside), and internal ones that encode the Databricks realm, as well as the Ontos specific one. This is all merged into a knowledge graph, representing the business ontology. Users can now use the graph to perform much more powerful searches, using inference with business semantics.

Ontos also supports a few other Data Governance related topics that support the overall usability. Think of an office building with workers performing business functions, while also having only a handful of facility staff that keeps the building in operations. Some of the recurring janitorial tasks are integrated into Ontos allowing a handful of dedicated personnel to set up security and managed multi-site metadata exchange. As with the diagram above, this metadata is added to the knowledge graph, allowing stewards to review which personas are assigned to data products, based on semantics.
Do all customers need to build an ontology now?

Yes and no - on the one hand, that would greatly improve the discoverability and reusability of data by both people and agents. On the other hand, it is a big investment of time and effort to build and maintain such a resource and that may be too much for many customers.
We should therefore simplify this in three ways:
From the perspective of gradual implementation, we define a hierarchy of expressivity, starting with a humble business glossary and growing up to a full ontology.
in the domain of interest that identify particular concepts. This may or may not include synonyms at this stage.
of controlled vocabulary terms that relates broader and narrower concepts. This will also include synonyms, enabling linkage of different taxonomies.
A taxonomy that also includes definitions of
that can exist between the concepts.
a graph together with an ontology
that defines the meaning of the concepts and relationships.

These artefacts traditionally live in isolation, maintained outside a data platform. One of the key features of Ontos is “semantic assignment”, making it simple to map a concept to the data that represents that concept.

Customers may be lucky enough to operate in an industry where a comprehensive standard ontology exists (e.g. FIBO for FSI, or any one of a wide range of ontologies for HLS). Since Ontos is built around the open and widely accepted RDF family of standards they can import such an ontology and immediately start using it as a basis to define the semantics of their data.

Alternatively, they may want to define their own set of concepts and relationships, and this should be an easy process. Tools like Palantir’s Foundry provide a very clean experience for this, albeit in a closed-source manner.

Finally, the metadata available in Unity Catalog provides the opportunity to automate much of the creation and maintenance process, potentially even using an Agentic approach. For example, the user is provided suggestions on concepts to attach to a particular securable based on the lineage or analysis of how the data is being used.

This combination of existing Databricks features with the additional capabilities provided by Ontos makes it practical to maintain an ontology close to the data in a way that has historically not been possible.

Databricks Apps is our path for n-fold growth, akin to when Oracle started offering vertical solutions on top of their RDBMS offerings. Our own platform cannot and should not add all the special features required for such vertical solutions (like loading arbitrary ontologies into the control plane), but should instead rely on apps to add such features, deeply embedded in the platform using all available building blocks, such as APIs, Lakebase, and DBSQL, Lakeflow, Tag Policies, and so on. Ontos does this for data management and
. It will become a fully featured application that enables business users to manage their data assets in a domain-oriented
. While we expect some features to be reintroduced to the platform, many can remain in the app permanently.

Many customers find Critical User Journey (CUJ) XYZ confusing, which limits its adoption (e.g., cited as a major pain point by customers A, B, C). This design reduces the steps to accomplish CUJ X by 50%, which we believe will improve the adoption of feature Y by 25%. See the
and markdown integration in GitHub to version control the diagrams, you can also use
to make lo-fi diagrams to copy into these documents
We want to introduce a component to My System to support use cases A, B, and C.
Alternative: Use an OSS solution like DataHub, or a commercial one like Collibra, Alation, Atlan etc.

While these products can handle similar functionality to some degree, none are as deeply embedded and as native as Ontos is. More specifically, all 3rd Party solutions (OSS or commercial) have little interest in giving control back to our platform once the users start using their own UI. It is common for these tools to mostly extract metadata into their service and then take over. It is hard to impossible to feed back defined business semantics from these tools so that other use-cases can benefit. Other tools aim at all incumbent services in a heterogeneous IT stack. Ontos does not need to do that as it ONLY runs inside Databricks. In addition, Ontos drives native $DBU consumption, while other SaaS offerings offload compute to their account as much as possible. Finally, Ontos serves as a Petri dish for our own PM to see what customers need in the platform, driving innovation and improvements directly.

One example of a partner who is touching on this concept is Kobai, however their product focuses more on modelling the business and providing a Knowledge Graph over Databricks and less on the Data Product elements.
Ontos relies on our platform to deliver on its promises, including Databricks Apps itself, but also Lakebase, Lakeflow, System Tables, and so on. If we
, we can fail. As evidence to the contrary, Kasal is running inside the platform (via the Marketplace) and has dozens of production users!

For some functionality, we need a) existing APIs, and b) bulk operation support. For instance, Ontos lets users create Genie Spaces out of Data Products. The API to do so must exist. Or, Ontos writes and reads tags from Unity Catalog. An efficient, non-single record API call to operate in bulk is dearly needed at scale.
How do you intend to track the usage of this proj

Answer: Ontos runs as a Databricks App, which means it can benefit from the existing service telemetry and dashboards. API calls could carry app information, akin to what is done in UCX to capture API calls from the app. At least, many API calls or CPU usage consumed via Lakeflow Jobs are directly attributable to the app's service principal. The jobs and other resources can also be tagged to surface usage metrics.
Once the app is available in the Marketplace, further metrics are produced on downloads etc.
There are various methods to track the usage of a Databricks Labs Project and attribute it to a number of DBUs. One or more of these can be employed. The preferred order is:
Whenever a library is imported from a package, that telemetry is tracked against the cluster it was imported on.
DLT clusters do not track this for some reason (investigating)
Spark Configs can be tracked when used on clusters
Cannot be set via spark.conf.set(). Rather, it can only be detected if set upon cluster creation.
Cannot contain anything that is considered PII, like table name. Value is unable to be redacted.
Whenever a labs project is installed via the CLI, it’s name is included in the
in the header. Other API calls to other Databricks endpoints can include the project name in the
along with other information, which can be detected.
Currently, the cluster_id is always redacted in the logs, which makes attributing labs projects to DBUs nearly impossible.
The lowest granularity therefore that can be attributed is to workspace.

Need to add spark config to spark config allowlist
